title: What is your favorite Shostakovich symphony? - Quora

response.answer_text: In order of composition, my favorites are: 4, 5, 8, 9, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15 It’s hard to say which of these I like best. The boldly experimental No. 4 holds a special fascination for me. Nos 5 & 10 are justly popular works on a grand scale. The dark and brooding #8 and the sassy and sarcastic #9 make compelling contrast. 15 is just an amazing final essay in the form—a sort of a “catch me if you can” symphony. This piece seems to be saying, at least to me: “You may think you understand DSCH, but you don’t. He’s always one step ahead of you.” 13 and 14 are powerful treatments of poetic texts. I suppose my favorite among these is the one I’m listening to at the moment. I just finished hearing #15, in a performance by the composer’s son Maxim and the Prague Symphony Orchestra. Hear Maxim (or anyone) if you can in this catch-me-if-you-can symphony.

8. A total monster of a piece. One of the bleakest pieces ever composed. In that rare class of pieces that after you know it, just feels like every single note is utterly critical and if it were a second shorter or longer, the whole thing might collapse. Written as the war accelerated to even darker places, the center of the piece (the 3rd movement) is manic, full of rounds and motion, but ultimately dissolves into 2 more movements of intense darkness. Shostakovich was criticized for making 7 an upbeat ode to the win at Stalingrad. 8 pretty much shuts that down hard.

The first piece of music I ever heard by Shostakovich was Symphony No 1 and it has always remained a firm favourite, though eclipsed slightly a little bit later by Nos 5, 7 and 10. The 4th is also strong with me, and I have soft spots for 11 and 12. Having said that an honourable mention goes to No 6 which has far more in its three movement frame than is at first apparent. I enjoy 8 and 9 but do not care much for 2, 3, 13, 14 or 15 - though I can listen to them if no other Shostakovich symphony is available.

I may sound very unsophisticated and undiscerning, but for me, nothing beats “Leningrad”. Nothing ever beats beautiful simplicity. Having said that, I love them all, but the 11th also has a special place in my heart. I am very unsophisticated, indeed.
I would choose the 6th. It has some bouyancy, but still the traffic drama of my 2 runners up, the 10th and 8th.
